body.p: I have a commission for you. My valuable friends in GloucestershireThe Cheltenham ladies write me thus:— "A Philanthropist of one genus puts me in mind of one of another order, Samuel Roberts, of Sheffield I believe, his printer is J. Blackwell, Sheffield.— This Good Man is truly interested in ameliorating the hard lot of Chimney Sweeping Boys and also of Gipsies.— I have tried ineffectually to get his publications which I particularly wanted to lend to a young clergyman whose feelings of humanity appeared to be sincerely developing towards the former class of unfortunate ill used begins, and I would fair have fostered this valuable opening in his mind by lending him S. Roberts' work on the subject containing prose and poetry; but the Bookseller in London said it was out of print."

If you can pick me up this work in Sheffield, pray do so, and if the price be not large, a dozen copies will be preferable to one. My friends are very lavish in their gift of useful books. And as to supplying me with money, they have made me rich! Their remittances already amount to two hundred pounds. I shall be sending you a parcel [[2]] before I got to London and will remit the price of the Books and any thing you will say is due to yourself or Mr Otley. Mrs C. and I are to go and visit these ladies before I return to Lancashire.— Tom Paine is here and will remain. If you will let T.T. JunrJunior come and spend his Christmas with him ; we can accommodate him well in my absence and my Chapel is already engaged for the Christmas Bells. I shall want him as a preacher by and bye : as you will see by an advertisement I am to send you. We are staying with Mr Campion, 44 Booth Street, Oxford Road, my old shopman.
I sent you a parcel lately with some tracts of mine and some Shepherd. I can send more Shepherd if you can make a pleasure in circulating them.

I shall leave Manchester for three weeks about the 20th Inst and wish to hear from you before that time. this is my 47th birthday. With care in the Winter, I think I shall wear a dozen years longer: but I must take care. Yorkshire air suits me better than Manchester.

[3]] Mrs C will return with me and lecture here and about ; and a trial will be made whether or not she has taken for a public life. I have never heard her lecture but once, that was to a small audience ; therefore I am no judge: but I mark that she has no study in philosophical matters; and on that I think much depends. I shall help on that head as I did in the Isis; but the feeling and originality is superior to the mechanical delivery of sentiment.

Tom Paine is likely to start here as a Bookseller. I must do as I did in 1820, run a new agency through the country: for I shall be bringing out a new class of books. There is no liken between me and the Radicals.

I am putting the Socialists to their tether on the Monday evening. It is astonishing how ill men bear discussion. These Socialists are as offensive and dishonest as any religious sect when brought to discussion. I find the same outcry against the Penny Admission here as there was about a shilling and sixpence at Sheffield.
[[4]] PS I kept my letter open until Tom returned from the Town, thinking that by possibility, I might hear from you. Sure enough I have. The Box is at Mr Heywood's and I dare say all is right.
As soon as my discussion with Green is ready, you shall have a parcel back.

I fancied I saw how things were going at Sheffield. I am not surprised at it. Frivolity seems more suited to the present state of the human mind than any sound, serious and permanent principle. notwithstanding, I feel myself right enough for the future: and rejoice in the course I have taken.
